quotes.topic_title: Yuhki’s career arc to Figma CPO

quotes.topic_title: Yuhki’s career arc to Figma CPO
quotes.text: But at Uber, I realized that I wanted to dip my toes into design directly. For the tail end, I actually switched from PM to design and managed a few design teams working on our bikes and scooter efforts just to understand what that's like.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A concrete example of building empathy and skill by temporarily switching functions instead of only collaborating cross-functionally.

quotes.topic_title: Yuhki’s career arc to Figma CPO
quotes.text: It was a time in the company where we were trying to transform our culture to be much more transparent and inclusive, and Figma was the perfect fit for that.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita

quotes.topic_title: Yuhki’s career arc to Figma CPO
quotes.text: as a product manager who's been straddling that boundary between design and products for all my career, I really loved how Figma proactively blurred that boundary and opened up that process of participating in design.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A memorable product principle: reduce handoffs by intentionally blurring functional boundaries to broaden participation.

quotes.topic_title: Switching from PM to design and back
quotes.text: Well, I decided it's not for everyone, but I think that it's, first of all, a really great empathy building exercise of understanding that point of view, and also pushing yourself to push on the product from a different angle.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Highlights switching into design as a practical way for PMs to build empathy and expand how they influence product quality.

quotes.topic_title: Switching from PM to design and back
quotes.text: Because I think as a PM, you're in the center facilitating all these different trade offs, and when you go into design, you have to ignore some of those other aspects to really be insistent on pushing on the best experience possible.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Offers a mental model: PM optimizes tradeoffs, while design temporarily suspends them to push for the best user experience.

quotes.topic_title: Switching from PM to design and back
quotes.text: Just suspend everyone's disbelief in business feasibility or engineering feasibility to push on a vision.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for design-mode thinking: deliberately set aside feasibility constraints to explore a stronger product vision.

quotes.topic_title: Switching from PM to design and back
quotes.text: When I became manager of design teams, one of the things that I coach designers on, are how to win over PMs, and how to speak in PM's language, and likewise, it's important for PMs to understand that, as well.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Emphasizes cross-functional influence as a learnable skill—designers and PMs should translate for each other to collaborate effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Switching from PM to design and back
quotes.text: I would say managing designers is harder than managing product managers.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about leadership difficulty that can reshape how leaders approach managing different disciplines.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling as a core PM leadership skill
quotes.text: And I actually think that a lot of being a great product manager is being a great storyteller.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Frames storytelling not as a soft skill but as a core competency for PM effectiveness and leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling as a core PM leadership skill
quotes.text: And so that's common advice, here, but I think the most powerful part of that is that in some ways, you can synthesize what happened.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Recasts “take notes” as an opportunity to create leverage by distilling meetings into a forward-driving narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling as a core PM leadership skill
quotes.text: And the other aspect of storytelling, of course, is a story is only as good as the action that it's capable of driving.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Defines a practical bar for storytelling: it must translate into decisions and movement, not just clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Storytelling as a core PM leadership skill
quotes.text: And I often talk about memification, which is this idea that I found this out most at Uber, I feel, where there's certain insights, data insights, research insights that were memmified to the point where someone like Travis or Dara would just cite this insight in the middle of a meeting, and you know that you've really done your job as, maybe, a researcher or a data scientist or product manager if people are able to do that and draw from that in that way.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Introduces “memification” as a concrete test for whether insights are sticky enough to spread and influence leadership decisions.

quotes.topic_title: How to improve storytelling in practice
quotes.text: Yeah, I think of it as resetting the internal computer of my brain a little bit so that I start from scratch again.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A practical mental model for escaping the curse of knowledge by deliberately rebuilding the narrative from zero context.

quotes.topic_title: How to improve storytelling in practice
quotes.text: And when I'm starting from no context at all, can I build up the story from bare and explain what's happening?
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A concrete self-check practitioners can use to test whether their story is understandable to newcomers.

quotes.topic_title: How to improve storytelling in practice
quotes.text: I guess the way to think about it is, put yourself in another user's shoes, and that user is someone who has no idea what's happening and still wants to understand, in a nuanced enough way, what you're grappling with.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A clear audience-definition heuristic: optimize for a zero-context listener while preserving nuance.

quotes.topic_title: How to improve storytelling in practice
quotes.text: Yeah, I think another thing that where I learned storytelling is through teaching.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Suggests an actionable way to build storytelling skill faster: practice by teaching concepts to others.

quotes.topic_title: How to improve storytelling in practice
quotes.text: So when I was a course assistant for a computer science class and I had to explain pointers, you're like, okay, I really have to borrow on real world metaphors or something that is much more grounding because if you assume a lot of knowledge, then it can be inaccessible to a lot of people.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A specific example showing how using grounded metaphors improves clarity when the audience lacks prerequisite knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: PMs owning the “why” and five whys
quotes.text: But I do think the why is something that I really always hold the PM uniquely responsible for.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Defines a clear ownership boundary for PMs: not the idea itself, but the underlying rationale that guides the team.

quotes.topic_title: PMs owning the “why” and five whys
quotes.text: So then it's like, how do they make a really great decision? How do they make all these local decisions that you're not a part of, how do you make it so that a great decision's made? And if everyone has an understanding of why we're doing this, what problem we're solving, then people can make really great decisions. It's the only way you can really scale.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Connects “owning the why” to scalable decision-making by enabling high-quality local decisions without PM involvement.

quotes.topic_title: PMs owning the “why” and five whys
quotes.text: So for example, our engineering team at Figma, whenever we do a retro or postmortem, we do this thing called five why's.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Shares a concrete operational practice (five whys) used at Figma to drive learning and improvement after incidents.

quotes.topic_title: PMs owning the “why” and five whys
quotes.text: And I think a PM can do this, too, which is a customer is asking for a feature, but then you would say, okay, why are they asking for it, and back up the problem. But I think there's one more step you can take, which is, why do they have that problem in the first place? And maybe there's something there, and that could be an opportunity to make a bigger product impact by fixing that underlying condition that created the problem in the first place.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Applies the five-whys method to product discovery to move beyond feature requests toward root-cause opportunities with larger impact.

quotes.text: And that intuition is actually built off of thousands and hundreds of thousands of customer interactions where he might look at something and be like, "You know what? This isn't going to land well," or, "Here's the biggest problem right now."

quotes.context: Highlights a scalable mental model: strong product intuition is often the compounding result of massive customer exposure, not “gut feel” in isolation.

quotes.topic_title: Working with Dylan Field and customer obsession
quotes.text: And part of my job is to build out that logic streak for him of how did you arrive at that conclusion so that people can understand that at scale, in a way.

quotes.context: Actionable advice for product leaders: translate founder intuition into explicit reasoning so teams can align and execute at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Working with Dylan Field and customer obsession
quotes.text: But for Dylan, I think, it's very hard for him to really fully get bought into it until he sees the end implementation to viscerally feel if this is a good solution or not.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Counterintuitive process insight: some decision-makers can’t evaluate plans or intermediate artifacts—only a near-real experience convinces them.

quotes.topic_title: Working with Dylan Field and customer obsession
quotes.text: And then Dylan just went straight in there and wanted to ask what the biggest problems were or what's not working, and they started geeking out on some issue around Google fonts, and this is the first major interaction between the two of them.

quotes.context: Concrete example of “real-time” customer obsession: using any opportunistic moment to observe and interrogate actual user pain.

quotes.topic_title: Working with Dylan Field and customer obsession
quotes.text: And on one level it's just easy to say, "Hey, this is a single user who just happens to be using your product," and be dismissive with it or not care that deeply because you think you already know all the biggest problems, but that's not his attitude.

quotes.context: Challenges conventional wisdom about ignoring “anecdotes”: treating even one user interaction as valuable can sharpen product judgment.

quotes.topic_title: When great products miss: branching and merging adoption
quotes.text: Some of it was performance, some of it was, this is a foreign workflow and it just takes time, and us helping customers implement some of those workflows, we realized some gaps because we don't really use it that much ourselves.

quotes.topic_title: When great products miss: branching and merging adoption
quotes.text: And so, I think as we're getting bigger, one of the things that I'm realizing is that we're starting to build a lot of features that are not, necessarily, for organizations like ours.

quotes.context: A scaling insight: as your customer base diversifies, internal usage stops being a reliable proxy for product validation.

quotes.topic_title: When great products miss: branching and merging adoption
quotes.text: And when we do that, we really need to be creative about how we understand how effective those are because we've had such a strong culture of internal testing and dogs looting, and those are the things that really helped make sure the quality of our product was good enough.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to evolve validation methods beyond dogfooding when building for new customer types.

quotes.text: It's so important that you're using your own products.

quotes.context: A simple but high-leverage quality principle: dogfooding is foundational to building great software.

quotes.context: A concrete, counterintuitive workflow shift (memos → decks) used to force more internal product usage and surface quality issues.

quotes.topic_title: How Figma maintains high product quality
quotes.text: And so I think there are ways in which, sometimes, you have to get creative to enable your company, your entire company to use a product more.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A practical methodology: intentionally design internal processes to increase company-wide product touchpoints.

quotes.topic_title: How Figma maintains high product quality
quotes.text: And so that's the biggest thing. The more hours people are spending inside your product, internally, I think, just naturally becomes better.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita

quotes.topic_title: How Figma maintains high product quality
quotes.text: So I think that personal accountability can really make a difference.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up fixes, developer motivation, and OKR struggles
quotes.text: The first part, I would say that I think one of the most powerful things, especially for startups, is that bottoms up energy, and maybe a developer noticing something is wrong and just going off and fixing it. And for the most part, I try not to get in the way of that because if people are doing that constantly, and everyone the company is trying to make the product better, that is sometimes a way more effective way to improve the quality of experience than this top down of, oh, let's define this quality experience metric and try to change all the things, because you might miss these things.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A counterintuitive quality strategy: protect bottom-up fixes instead of over-indexing on top-down metrics programs.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up fixes, developer motivation, and OKR struggles
quotes.text: And the second thing is, I think a lot of PMs have grown to realize this, which is, if you ask an engineer about how much time it'll cost to go and build something, and it's something that they came up with or they're advocating for, it's almost always half the time as something that you are asking for, as a PM. And that motivation is so different.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for planning and influence: engineer-owned ideas tend to be faster because intrinsic motivation changes execution.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up fixes, developer motivation, and OKR struggles
quotes.text: And you encounter one of two situations. One is, you come up with some secondary metric that nobody actually cares about that, technically, you can measure and, technically, you can move, but you haven't actually proven that it really matters.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A crisp failure mode of OKRs: measurable proxy metrics that are movable but not meaningful.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up fixes, developer motivation, and OKR struggles
quotes.text: So either you anchor something that matters, but you can't move, or you anchor something that you can't move but doesn't actually matter.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why OKRs often fail in practice: the “matters vs. controllable” trap.

quotes.topic_title: Bottom-up fixes, developer motivation, and OKR struggles
quotes.text: And so that was when I deprecated it and said, "I just want to understand your headline. What are you trying to do, philosophically?" And just don't stress about whether you can measure it or not. I just don't understand what you're optimizing for, and let's first have that to date.
quotes.speaker: Yuhki Yamashita
quotes.context: An alternative operating method to OKR-first: start with a legible “headline” (intent) before forcing metrics.
